🚨New Article🚨in @monarch.wine - 🍷A Tale Of Two Wineries Exploring The Terroir Of The Okanagan🍷- ✨Featuring @quailsgate & @nkmipcellars
.
👉Follow my Link in Bio to read the interesting and coincidentally connected history of these two amazing Okanagan wineries
.
😉Here is a sneak peek:
Beauty and sheer presence are expressed in the glass when enjoying a British Columbia-made wine from the Okanagan. Powerful, ethereal, and poignant are all words that connect the wines of this Canadian region to the land around them.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
The Okanagan is the place to dip into the vast and diverse world of BC wines. Having an ever-changing terroir, as you pass through the wine regions of Lake Country and Kelowna into Peachland, Summerland, Penticton, the Naramata Bench, Skaha Bench and the Okanagan Falls, tree-lined views in the north change. Travelling southbound, the dramatic peaks of the Rockies become stunning rolling mountains. Further south through Oliver, the Golden Mile Bench, and Osoyoos, you have entered a different winemaking world that is arid and warm. Simply throughout a 2.5-hour drive.
⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀
Although a part of the Okanagan, Kelowna and Osoyoos present very different expressions of the wines of BC. While the entire region sits right below the 50th parallel, the same lateral area as Champagne. These two ends of it are worlds away in the glass. Quails' Gate Winery in Kelowna and Nk'Mip Cellars in Osoyoos embody this. Even though different, the pasts and presents of each sum up the winemaking landscape of the Okanagan
.
🤩I enjoyed visiting these wineries so much when I was in the Okanagan this past May. Both told me their unique stories, and the histories of both wineries instantly struck me. Although so far from each other but in the same region, I feel their presence gives great colour to the story of Okanagan winemaking 
.
💁🏻‍♀️Ready to dive into some winemaking history?

📸#HolidaySelfie - But who wouldn't? 🥂The spirited time of year is here!
.
🎁One place in Toronto that always brings the holiday spirit, The Distillery District, has relaunched its formerly named Christmas Market as The Distillery Winter Village. There are many picture-worthy moments as you explore the historic neighbourhood's cobblestone streets. Of course, the centrepiece is the more than 50-foot tall White Spruce Christmas Tree. This year designed by Parfums Christian Dior
.
🙌The Distillery Winter Village runs until December 31st. Filled with tones of selfies-moment locations, live performances, and The Great Gingerbread Hunt, you can give back this season all in one place!
Wish upon a star by purchasing a Wishing Star from the Info Booth. Write down your wish and hang it on one of the many smaller trees in the Winter Village. Every star gives back, forwarding $3 to benefit the Distillery's charitable partners, Salvation Army, Second Harvest and Stella's Place, for the holidays
.
🥂Widely regarded as Canada's premier holiday market, the Distillery Winter Village is open daily. Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Thursdays are free entry into the market. Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays have free access available till 4pm then entry tickets are required at $11 each. Check the Distiller Winter Village official website for the best times to visit
.
😉And don't forget to tag @distilleryTO and #DistilleryWinterVillage  then next time you go 
.
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be going to The Distillery Winter Village?
.
.
.
.
.
.

🤩Diving into flavour with @tasteusa.ca - 🍷Washington Chardonnay & 🍎Apples
.
🤓Terroir is a unique catch-all term in the wine world, summarizing somewhereness. That unique sense of place allows wine grapes to express themselves the way they do in wine form
.
🍇Explaining why you can try the same wine grape made in different areas and find that the wine will taste different. Even in winemaking regions that seem close, there can be many flavour differences
.
😉How wine expresses itself in the glass is one side of the equation, the other half of understanding wine to the fullest is about diving into aromas and flavours. The more time you take to climatize your nose and palate to understand and form memories of aromas and flavours, the better, you will be at truly knowing wine
. 
🍎Washington grows over 30 varieties of apples. Apples just so happen to be a primary flavour note in Chardonnay. It is a classic note in many Chardonnays around the world. Still, because many styles of apples grow in Washington, the state offers a unique set of circumstances for getting better acquainted with the apple notes in its Chardonnays
.
🍷Washington Chardonnay grapes benefit from the long sunlit days and cool brisk nights during the growing season. Creating Chardonnay wines that are bright and delicate, with ample aromas and a palate to match with a crisp finish. Of all the apples Washington grows, two stand out in their Chardonnays the most – Jonagold apples and Granny Smith. The sweet honey-scent notes of the Jonagold and the soft but lemon-like character of the Granny Smith translate into the glass with Washington Chardonnays
.
🤓Creating those aromas and flavour memories is the key to improving your palate and exploring the best of what tasting USA has to offer
.
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be diving into this flavour experience?
.
[Sponsored Partnership with Taste USA]

🥂Ca’ del Bosco, Simply Franciacorta - 👉New Article in @monarch.wine
.
🥂If there is one wine you should explore more this holiday season, it is Franciacorta. The gem of the Italian north, this wine style is infamous, delicious, and sipped continuously by those in the know of great bubbly wines. Made in the metodo classico style and often called Italy’s answer to Champagne. Maurizio Zanella, owner of one of the region’s most prolific wineries, Ca’del Bosco, would rather say there is no comparison to Franciacorta
.
🍷Franciacorta is, Franciacorta – a wine that coincidentally has bubbles. Put into greater context, the comparisons of the Lombardy sparkling homeland to the rest of the world of bubbles have only a couple of points in common
.
😉Follow my Link in Bio to read on - BUT here is a sneak peek
👇👇👇
✨The experience of enjoying a glass of Franciacorta is like sipping on a sunny pillow. Bright with boldness, complex with a rounder texture, and weighted with a sense of elegance. The entire vineyard lands of Franciacorta sit in an amphitheatre-like shape around the southern half of Lake Iseo. A land filled with mineral-rich soils, the region’s rolling hills benefit from the warm microclimate quelled by cool breezes that descend from the alps in the north.

✨Chardonnay, Pinot Noir, Pinot Blanco and Erbamat (the revived native grape to the region) are the grapes behind every bottle, with most vineyards growing organically, Ca’del Bosco included. Chardonnay brings richness, Pinot Noir brings structure, Pinot Blanco lends floral and citrus notes, and Erbamat is proving to add mineral and earthy notes. From Non-Vintage to Satèn, Rosé, Millesimato, and Riserva, the sense of place brought to the glass brings notes of fruit flavours, soft nuttiness and richness that edges on the divine
.
👉Find @cadelbosco_official Franciacorta at the @LCBO
. 
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be sipping on some Italian bubbly this holiday season?

🍷What Grows Together Goes Together - Exploring the Aromas and Flavours of Washington, Oregon and California Wines with @tasteusa.ca
.
🤩Washington, Oregon and California are big players in American winemaking, not to mention agriculture too! All three states have put themselves on the map for great experiences exploring flavour
.
😉But did you know that wines in these regions also express the flavour and aroma notes of popular produce grown in each state?
.
🍷How wine expresses itself in the glass is one side of the equation, the other half of understanding wine to the fullest is all about diving into the nitty-gritty of knowing aromas and flavours
.
🤓Yes, this does sound a bit esoteric. However, the more time you take to climatize your nose and palate to understand and form memories of aromas and flavours, the better you will be at truly knowing wine. Washington, Oregon and California grow fruits that are classic flavour notes in each state's wines. Getting more acquainted with what grows in these regions can improve your abilities and aid in becoming a bonafide wine enthusiast
.
🍇Understanding wine to the fullest is all about creating aromas and flavour memories. The more you explore, the more you will decode what is happening in the glass!
.
👉Follow my Link in Bio to read on
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you in for exploring Washington, Oregon and California wines in the glass?
.
[Sponsored Partnership with Taste USA]

🍷Classic, gift-worthy and made for the holidays - Amarone is the way to go
.
🎁Every time I am asked about an ideal red wine for the holidays, whether it is as a bottle to gift or to enjoy, Amarone is at the top of the list of recommendations. From a classic winemaking region, made in a style that is unique to the region and from a place filled with stories behind the bottle is why Amarone wines make a perfect complement to the holidays
.
🤩On the flavour side of things, Amarone wines are big and bold. While from the Old World, made in the Valpolicella zone just west of Verona in Italy, this is a wine style that is great for wine lovers who gravitate towards similarly styled wines. Like California Cabernets, Gran Riserva Rioja, GSM Blends from Australia and bold Malbecs from Argentina - these are the palate suited to love Amarone to the fullest 
.
🤓Made by the Cottini family, the winery was started by Diego Cottini and named after his wife, Annaberta. Villa Annaberta is in its fourth family generation of ownership, run by Michele and Mattia, their sons. A love letter to their mother, this is a wine that brings in the history of family and the region into the glass to create a Harmonious, elegant and complex Amarone della Valpolicella DOCG production
.
🍷Filled aromas of black cherry, blackberry and wild dark fruit notes, All mixed with bold pieces and dried fruits. On the palate, you are greeted by silky tannins, a balanced wine and one that ends with a long finish
.
🥂Wrapped up for gifting or paired with rich sauces, matured cheese, and every grilled veg and meats this bottle is now on shelves at the @LCBO for the holidays
.
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be giving the gift of Amarone this holiday season?
.
[Sponsored Partnership with Dionysus Wines & Spirits]

🍾Crowd-pleasing and ready for a good pairing, who is in for a glass of Valpolicella Ripasso?
.
🍷If there is one wine I would always recommend as a compromise to pair with so much and deliver next to a meal, it is hands down a Valpolicella Ripasso. This younger and fresher-styled wine of the Valpolicella region is ideal for those moments. And to be honest, I have rarely (if ever) had a Ripasso that I didn’t enjoy to the fullest!
.
🤓Often called Baby Amarone Ripassos are made by fermenting the light and regionally native grapes of the Valpolicella zone into a primary wine from fresh grapes. Followed by doing a second fermentation with Amarone skins, adding depth and complexity to the wine with has skin contact technique. Differing from Amarone, where the wine is solely made from dried grapes, the name Ripasso even comes from the repassing of the Amarone skins as part of the winemaking process
.
🍇Made from Corvina, Corvinone, and Rondinella, the Villa Annaberta Valpolicella Ripasso Superiore DOC is a beautiful ruby colour. Filled with notes that are savoury, toasted and licorice-like. There is a delightful florality and fruit-ladenness to the wine for a full aromatic feel. On the palate, there is brightness and lift, dried fruit flavours, spices and approachable tannins
.
👉Find this bottle at the @LCBO and give it a try with some of your holiday favs. I am a fan of pairing this wine is Palak Paneer, a staple in our home around the holidays. But this wine is great with almost any dish you can throw. It is the amazing power of Valpolicella Ripasso!
.
💁🏻‍♀️What would you pair with the Villa Annaberta Ripasso?
.
[Sponsored Partnership with Dionysus Wines & Spirits]

.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you ready for some holiday cheer?

🥂Who says the cool weather is only a red wine affair?
.
🍇Etna Bianco’s are based on the grape Carricante. A native grape to the region that, when placed in the perfect terroir elements, can make for a very compelling and memorable experience in the glass. And while it might be cold outside, these are wines that do conjure up some warming images from whence they came, evoking seaside, volcanos, warmer weather thoughts
.
🤓Tornatore has been making wine on Etna all the way back to the 1800s. In 1865 the great-grandfather of Francesco Tornatore, Giuseppe, built the winery in the Piano Fiera area of Etna and planted vineyards on the north side of the volcano in Piano Felci. The slopes on this side of the volcano are not as steep as the south and are characterized by mild temperatures and soils made up of black volcanic rock
.
🤩Tornatore’s wines show the intensity of this volcanic region and decades of winemaking knowledge in the glass. When it comes to making their Etna Bianco, Carricante grapes are hand-harvested from vineyards growing at 650m a.s.l, and the wine is vinified in a temperature-controlled style to bring out the fitness of this grape. This is followed by 3 months of lees ageing and maturation in steel and concrete tanks to add complexity to the palate
.
🍷In the final wine, it is hard not to feel like you are not experiencing Etna in the glass. There is a push and pull of beautiful floral and citrus notes combined with the minerality and salinity of the region’s terroir. The wine is alive, exuberant, electric and captivating
.
👉Find this bottle on @LCBO store shelves now 
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you in for a winter white from Etna?

🎁Explore a new bottle this holiday with @winesofportugal_ca 🍷
.
🇵🇹Portuguese wines are on trend right now. The country known for making Port does more than create the classic fortified wine. This country is filled with great diversity to try in the glass, being home to over 250 native grape varieties!
.
🤓This is a time of year when we often see big and bold red wines bring drought to the table. With its modern, inspiring, daring, and passionate wines, Portugal makes for great gifts and perfectly suits the holiday season. Plus, while there is a lot of history to be explored in the glass, the modern age of Portuguese wines represents the Old World but strikes a unique balance between traditional and modernity
.
🍇One of the top regions to explore for fabulous Portuguese reds is Douro. One of the wildest and most rugged winemaking regions in the country, the terroir of the region is defined by the Douro River. One of the richest regions for indigenous grapes and home to many old vine planting. When it comes to making red wines in the Douro, 5 red wine grapes stand out - Tinta Barroca, Tinta Roriz, Tinto Cão, Touriga Franca and Touriga Nacional
.
🍷In the glass and also currently on @LCBO shelves is the @vicente_faria_vinhos Animus Douro DO red blend of 40 % Touriga Franca, 30 % Tinta Roriz and 30 % Touriga Nacional
😍Filled with fruit-leading aroma notes of blackberry, black plum, black cherry, dates, dried purple fig, chocolate and licorice. Followed by a palate that is rustic and sitting on the medium side with ripe tannins and a long finish
.
🎁A perfect holiday gifting bottle for red wine lovers that are interested in exploring more of what the Old World has to offer
.
🤩This month, I will be diving into more Portuguese wines and  pairing them up with some seasonal delights along the way
.
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be sipping Portuguese wine this holiday?
.
[Sponsored Partnership with Wines of Portugal]

🍷Cool-weather, bold wines and serving Portugal in the glass with @casarelvas & @winesofportugal_ca
.
😍Bold reds are a hallmark of the cool weather of winter. This time of year brings out a pension for red wines, as many wine lovers are switching to red wines just in time for the holiday season. Portugal is amazing, with winemaking regions crafting red wines for the moment!
.
🤓In the southern reaches of Portugal is the rolling plains region of Alentejo. Almost a third of the country’s mainland Alentejo is known for making some powerful red wines. The red blends of the region tend to be generous, warm and easy to love. They also pair great with foods of the holiday season
.
🍇The São Miguel Escolha dos Enologos 2020 is made by Casa Relvas from vineyards in the Alentejo sub-region of Redondo. The wine is a blend of mainly Touriga Franca, Touriga Nacional, Alicante Bouschet and other local varieties. All gained for 9 months in 400L French oak barrels 
.
🍷Named the ‘oenologist’s’ choice, in the glass, the wine gives aromatic notes that are peppery, filled with black and red fruit notes, mineral, floral and a touch earthy and smokey. On the palate, this is a round, rich and voluminous wine with balanced acidity, fine tannins and a long, complex finish
.
🥗Pair perfectly with seasonal dishes like roast beef and fabulously with vegetarian options like Moroccan bissara soup or roasted squash. This is a wine with notes of the holidays that complement each bit to the fullest
.
👉Find this bottle and other Portuguese red blends for the holidays at the @LCBO 
🍷These wines, with unique character and terroir, are a perfect match for a good meal at home
.

🍷Diving into flavour with @tasteusa.ca - Oregon Pinot Noir & Cranberries
.
😉Watch any wine-forward movie, and you will inevitably hear vinophiles rattling off wine notes. Swirling, smelling and tasting their glasses and calling out notes like apples, prunes, cranberries, the list can go on and on
.
🍇You might be thinking to yourself one of two things.
Firstly, there is no way they are smelling and tasting all that in the glass; wine just tastes and smells like wine. 
Or second, you may wonder if wine isn’t made from just grapes, but instead, a whole concoction of fruits that bring all these flavours to the glass
.
🤓As mind-blowing as it is to believe, grapes and grapes alone present the various aromas and flavours in wine. But the key to understanding those flavours to the fullest is all about getting a grasp on terroir and forming aroma and flavour memories
.
😍Oregon, this state is a significant producer of fresh cranberries. America’s original superfruit, this tangy berry, has been a part of American life since the 1550s. Oregon is one of the few states that grows cranberries while at the same time making stellar Pinot Noir. Willamette Valley Pinot Noirs are even famed for the cranberry flavour notes that they have
.
🍷The warm and dry summers of the region, mixed with the ocean air, produces Pinot Noirs with beautiful red berry fruit notes and great acidity on the palate. The character of fresh cranberries is translated through the vine and into Oregon Pinot Noirs
.
🤩So munching on a couple of cranberries from time to time can help train your nose and palate to pick up on these cranberry notes better. The more you explore, the more you will decode what is happening in the glass!
.

🤩Diving into flavour with @tasteusa.ca - California Cabernet Sauvignon & 🍒Black Cherries
.
🤯As mind-blowing as it is to believe, grapes and grapes alone present the various aromas and flavours in wine. It is a pretty nuts notion when you think about it, but it all has to do with a winemaking concept called terroir
.
🍇Terroir is why you can try the same wine grape made in different areas and find that the wine will taste different. Take Cabernet Sauvignons from California. They are bolder than those from elsewhere in the States precisely because of the expression of California’s terroir in the glass. Picking out the flavours that make Cali Cabs, well, Cali Cabs is all about getting a better sense of the aromas and flavours within the glass
.
🍒The largest winemaking region in the whole of the USA. California is known for its ability to produce great food and wine. If you have dipped your toes into California wines, you would already know by now that Cabernet Sauvignon is King in California. Rich in flavour and high in tannins, one of the classic notes that you can find in California Cabs is black or dark cherries
.
🤓And just like the wine grapes that started the California wine industry, cherries too were brought to the state by Spanish missionaries. Both industries had their ups and downs. It is easy to remember Prohibition and the Judgement of Paris tasting by Steven Spurrier comparing California wine with French on the wine side of things. However, in the same decade as that famous tasting, the State went all in on black or dark cherries
.
🍷With their sweet flavours that pull in woody and nut-like aromas, Black Cherries are a part of the flavours and aromas of California Cabernet Sauvignons. Getting more acquainted with this flavour and aroma can improve your abilities and aid in becoming a bonafide wine enthusiast
.
💁🏻‍♀️Have you picked up this key flavour note in your last glass of Cali Cab?
.

🥂Time to unwarp my favourite present to me - Champagne!
.
🍾Nothing like popping a bottle of bubbles to celebrate or gifting yourself a bottle to end the year. But as an academic drinker, I enjoy Champagne so much for a couple more reasons. Champagne wines are truly an expression of the terroir and culture of the region. They blend grapes, vineyards, vintages, and winemaking styles
.
🇫🇷The region had a history of trying to make still wine, and while the bubbles were an accident and originally seen as a flaw, people loved it! 
🤓There are Cooperatives, Vignerons, and larger Maisons like @champagnetaittinger, all creating wine in a range of styles from Brut Nature to Doux (sweet) and crafting Champagne wines that are Blanc de Blancs, Blanc de Noirs, and Rosés in either the vintage or non-vintage style
.
🥂Older Maisons like Taittinger has a storied background. This house was started by a wealthy textile merchant Jacques Fourneaux nearly 300 years ago before Pierre Taittinger bought it in the 1930s. Keeping it in the family, the winery is family-run by Pierre and his children Clovis and Vitalie. One of the largest producers in Champagne, the house is known for creating an expression in the glass that is fruity, floral and driven by the Chardonnay grape
.
🎁Wrapping this bottle as a gift to myself, it is time to pop the cork, finally. And while I can take the classic Sommelier route and go for a quiet pop, today feels like a moment to celebrate the year, so we are going classic celebration style
.
🤩The Taittinger Brut Réserve Champagne is a blend of 40% Chardonnay, 35% Pinot Noir and 25% Pinot Meunier, using perfectly matured grapes harvested from over 35 different vineyards. A non-vintage that expresses the house in the glass, one that is light elegant, balanced and lifted
.
🥂Cheers 2022, let’s finish off the celebrations with a @tastefrancemagazine #TasteFrance moment!
.
💁🏻‍♀️Will you be gifting yourself a bottle of Champagne?
.

🤩#TasteFrance with a classic pairing for the season - Alsace Riesling and Munster-Géromé Cheese
.
🍷Classic wine and food pairings are classic for a reason. These food and wine combinations have grown together, and when you experience the two in tandem, it is clear that they are mates for life
.
🇫🇷Alsace is west of the Vosges Mountains and right on the cusp of Germany. Alsace is known for Riesling. Compared to its neighbour in the west, Alsatian Rieslings are dry and bolder and fuller in body. Although still carrying those classic Riesling notes of high aromatic intensity
.
🍇If you are a Riesling lover, you know how showstopping these wines can be. A staple producer in the region @alsacewillm has been satisfying epicurean palates for over 120 years. Their Réserve Riesling features floral aromas, flavours of citrus,  juniper, beeswax and herbs. Dry on the palate and very textural
.
🧀For a great pairing alongside this Alsace Riesling is the equally aromatic cheese, Munster. Made from milk from Vosgiennes cows, the rind and aroma of Munster are key to making this cheese. Brine washed the pale rind of the cheese becomes a bold red/orange colour and brings in the distinctively savoury and stinky aromas Munter’s are known for
.
🤩There is no truer statement than what grows together goes together with these two. The savoury, pungent aromas of the cheese are matched perfectly by the floral and intense aromatics of the wine. Together making for a magical combination!
.
💁🏻‍♀️Have you explored this classic pairing before?
.

🍷Feeling the cozy winter vibes alongside a glass of Beaujolais 
.
🪩The holiday parties are done, all the gifts have been given, and the family and friend events have been attended. What am I in for now? If you guessed getting cozy on the couch, you would be right on the money
.
🛋️To pair with a day of relaxation, I am in for a glass of Beaujolais. Beaujolais has its own style, flavours, terroir and culture to match the wines made there. Once you leave the Mâconnais, you are in Beaujolais country!
.
🍇The Gamay grape, so well known for its starring role in Beaujolais wines, was banished from the northern half of Burgundy in 1620. However, it turned out to be a blessing in disguise as the granite soils of the region turned out to be the perfect partner for Gamay
.
🍷All resulting in a glass of wine that shows off a @tastefrancemagazine #TasteFrance moment. With bright acidity, low tannins and aromas and flavours that are reminiscent of raspberry, red cherry, red currant, and cranberries notes
.
🤩In the glass is Pisse-Dru. The @pissedrucanada Beaujolais starting from the name itself, is an expression describing how readily juice runs from ripe grapes. This is a plush wine with an easy-drinking vibe, plum, nutty, spice and red fruit flavours that are perfect for the day I have mapped out for myself 
.
🥂The funny thing about being in wine is that wine study is not always about reading a book. Sometimes it is all about taking in a new wine to the fullest. The intensity of life around that holiday can be easily done with a cozy moment to yourself 
.

.
🥃Crafted in South Africa, For over a decade, Nic and Di Davis have shared a farm with fifth-generation Breede Valley wine farmers, Coenie and Edelgard Lategan. In late 2017 the friends decided to bring their vast and varied skills and experience to the realm of independent gin distilling
.
✨Just as Monks and other amazing South African Gins Distillers were being established, Hanneli VD Merwe started Barker & Quin, a partnership between herself and long-time colleague and friend Chris Wium. It is the perfect sparking comment to SA Gin for cocktails
.

👇👇👇👇
🍹The Monks Gin MYSTERIUM, infused with an elixir of fynbos and sceletium. Creating a gin that is filled with notes of sweet melon, caramel aromas, juniper, savoury notes and undertones of orange peel and herbs
👉Paired with the Barker and Quin:
✨The Raspberry Tonic makes for a berry bright moment

.

.

🚨New Article Drop🚨 in @ddmtoronto - 🍷5 Wine Trends To Watch in 2023
.
🥂After much-needed time off, I am back in action with wine trends to watch out for. Now that 2023 has kicked off, here are some of the latest wine trends you will see this year
👉Follow my Link In Bio to get the full DL
.
🍇Emerging Wine Regions Are Taking Center Stage
🤓You might have noticed more wines from Portugal, Greece, and Canada on wine lists in the last couple of years. These global winemaking countries finally took their place in cellars and poured into the glasses of wine lovers. If you have loved their work, yes, it is about time. Beyond that, we also see more consumers dive into underdog winemaking regions from famous wine countries
.
🍷Natural Wines Have Hit The Mainstream
🤓It has finally happened! The I-told-you-so moment for Natural Wine lovers is here. Natural Wines are now mainstream. Natural, sulphur-free, unfine and unfiltered wines were once on the fringes of the wine world, but the tide has now fully turned
.
🥂Bubbles Are Not Just for Celebrations Anymore
🤓Words sommeliers have been uttering for a long time. Sparkling wines are not just for celebrations. It only took a pandemic to change this long-lasting trend, started by the great Champagne houses. Swinging the pendulum in the opposite direction, more wine drinkers pour themselves a glass of bubbly daily. 
.
🍾No And Low ABV Wines Are Gaining Traction
🤓NOLO, ever seen this term on the bar menu or wine list? Standing for No and Low Alcohol. This style of wine beverage has been gaining traction. Not all adults drink, but all adults might want a drink that isn't pop, water or coffee to go with a meal. NOLO options have been slowly but surely making their way onto store shelves
.
🌿Drinking Green Is The Way To Be
🤓Millennials and elder Gen Zers are part of the wine consumption market. This group has quickly become one of the most valuable demographics in wine. Representing a side of the marketplace that prioritizes inclusivity and sustainability. With all this in mind, it is no wonder that green wines are on the rise
.
💁🏻‍♀️What wine trends are you in for trying more in 2023?
.
.
.
📸Photo by @frontrowlady

🍷Sipping on some Lazio Wine - @casaledelgiglio Satrico is finally at the @LCBO
.
🍇Featuring a blend of Chardonnay, Sauvignon Blanc, and Trebbiano Giallo grapes, the Satrico by Casale del Giglio is as iconic as the Lazio region winery that made it!
.
🍷If this is the first time you have heard about the wines of Lazio, unfortunately, it is not surprising. Sommeliers have been touting this region as made for high-quality wines for some time. Lucky for Lazio, the tides are changing, and it is gaining that much-deserved recognition. Satrico is a sentiment to all the greatness this underdog region can produce
.
🙌Named after the ancient pre-Roman city of Satricum, where the winery is based today, but under a different name. Satrico is an elegant, aromatic and crisp wine filled with aroma notes of bright yellow apple, tart apricot, lime, herbaceous notes and white flowers that smell like they have been grown river-side - complemented on the palate by a mouth-wateringly crisp texture, lengthy finish and oh-so fantastic flavour
.
🍷A perfect wine to pair with those opening night moments, Satrico is a refreshing starting glass. This wine brings together the uniqueness of Italian grapes and world-travelling varietals. It is a wine ideal for serving alongside appetizers and lighter fare, making for a memorable experience that shows what Lazio can do in the glass
.
😉Like they say when in Rome, drink wine as the Romans do. And hey, if you are not in Rome, you should fill your glass with the wines Romans drink.

.

🤩Something unique in wine seems to be brewing in 2023
.
🥂Lately, I have been diving into what to expect for 2023. Something I do every January keeps an eye out for trends I have seen in the past compared to new wine trends that might pop up in the new year. While we are only a couple of days into 2023, it is noticeable that 2023 looks to hold a blurring of wine styles this year
.
🍷Wine is a broad category. The list goes on: red, white sparkling, still, fortified, orange. Over the last couple of years, wine lists and tastes have shifted. When I worked as a Sommelier in restaurants, I often asked if a guest was interested in a wine style, followed by if they liked lighter or heavier wines. But I see these conversations evolve
.
🤓Wine conversations are shifted to a focus on flavour, pairing options have bloomed, and wine is not just for a meal, with bottles being served before the meal begins and long after. If you have worked in wine for sometime al, all of this might seem very every day but the unique thing about 2023 is that we are seeing more of these conversations and actions coming from regular wine lovers
.
🙌While it might seem small, the blurring of styles and tastes tells me that the wine-loving public is becoming savvier. They know what they like and are exploring all the facets of wine. And I couldn't;t be happier about it!
.
💁🏻‍♀️I am so excited about what 2023 has in store, what are you looking forward to this year?
.
.
.
.
.
.

🍷Casale del Giglio is a winery that has become synonymous with the modern-day wine culture of the Eternal City. The perfect wine to transport yourself to Rome in the glass, Casale del Giglio's white wine blend Satrico is now on LCBO shelves
.
🤓There has been a renaissance of Lazio wines recently. Lazio's affordable and delicious wines mix international grapes and traditional native varieties. Sommeliers have been touting this region as made for high-quality wines for some time. This winemaking region is known for its volcanic soils and seaside influences, producing wines that show nuance, creativity, and longevity. They are deeply expressive
.
🍇An emerging onto the world stage, the tides have finial shifted in the trending direction for this Italian wine region. Cheers to that! Lazio is gaining some much-deserved recognition
.
🍷Naming the Satrico after the ancient pre-Roman city of Satricum, Casale del Giglio has a knack for combining the region's history with what Roman wines are today. Their wines are Lazio IGT productions that fit the modern culture of Roman life. A food-friendly Italian wine with memorability beyond its remarkable flavour ready to be paired, sipped, swirled and enjoyed
.

🍇Diving into more wine this year with emerging wine regions!
.
😉You might have noticed more wines from Portugal, Greece, and Canada on wine lists in the last couple of years. These global winemaking countries finally took their place in cellars and poured into the glasses of wine lovers. 
.
🥂If you have loved their work, yes, it is about time. Beyond that, we also see more consumers dive into underdog winemaking regions from famous wine countries. Think Franciacorta, Sherry, the Rhône Valley outside Châteauneuf-du-Pape and areas like the Finger Lakes and Washington in the USA
.
🙌All of these are making wine that is delicious, enjoyable and worthy of your time to try in the glass!
.
🤓Why are these regions making their way into our wine lexicons now? 
🍷More established regions like Napa, Burgundy, Bordeaux and the like are pricey, and vineyard land is in limited supply. With those two factors in tow, more fabulous winemakers verge into emerging regions to craft great wine. And done for a price tag that tends to be much easier to handle. You can grab yourself a good bottle for pennies by comparison
.
🍾Unbound by the cache of established regions, new wine lovers building their collections are seeing the value and are excited to see what these not-often-tasted regions are up to. So expect to see more wines from emerging regions on wine store shelves this year
.
💁🏻‍♀️What emerging regions are you enjoying wine from this year?
.
.
📸 by @frontrowlady

🍹NO/LO Cocktails are here to stay. I dive into 3 must-tries on @breakfasttelevision with @sid_seixeiro and @dawnchubai
.
🤓The No/Lo trend has been going on for quite a while now. The idea behind the trend is largely inclusive drinking without sacrificing flavour and keeping the convivial nature of enjoying a drink together
.
🍹No-ABV cocktails are those that have no alcohol at all. The benchmark for great drinks in this category is those with no alcohol but bring great flavour. 
🍹On the Lo-ABV side are drinks that have a significantly lower level of alcohol, done with intention and still delightful but a great conscious choice
.
Give a try to these No/Lo Cocktails 
👇👇👇👇👇
.
🍹A Sour Cocktail with @seedlipdrinks Spice 94
An aromatic non-alc alternative that gives notes of allspice, cardamon, grapefruit and oak 
✨Done in a cocktail with:
2oz of Seedlip Spice 94
1oz of Lemon/Grapefruit juice
0.5oz Ginger Syrup
2 pulls of @bettersbitters Miraculous Foamer
Garnish with a Lemon Twist, and enjoy!
.
🍹Pop open a can of pre-made Mojito by @clevermocktails and garnish it up!
✨Serve the Mojito as intended with a glass filled with ice, mint and limes.
Pour in the Clever Mocktails Mojito, and you are in business. This is such a flavourful option!
.
🥂Finally, a LO-ABV take on the Champagne cocktail with @drink.ones 1% Rosé Sparkling wine from the Okanagan. This is a great wine on its own, made with Pinot Noir and Chardonnay 
But subbing it in instead of Champagne makes a great lower-alcohol cocktail 
✨Just take:
0.25oz Cognac
1 teaspoon of sugar 
Stir the two together over ice and pour into Flute Glasses
Pop in a Lemon Twist 
Top with 3oz of Ones+ Sparkling Rosé
.

.

😍Amore! 😍Amore! 🍷Viva single-vineyard Amarone by @brigaldara
.
🤩Amarone is a wine that always has me wrapped around its finger during the cooler months of the year. With a name that evokes love and the warmth this wine shows in the glass between the holiday times of last year and with Valentine’s Day around the corner, Amarone is a wine style that has been on my mind a lot lately
.
🍷In the glass today, I have the single-vineyard wine the Amarone della Valpolicella Cavolo by Brigaldara
.
🤓A family-run winery, Brigaldara has passed from family hands to family hands since the 1920s. Today Brigaldara covers 120 hectares of land, housing vineyards, olive groves, crops and pastures. It is a monumental site that is run sustainably. The family, led by Stefano and Maria Gilla, with their two sons Antonio and Lamberto, work alongside their winemakers and agronomists to attend to the needs of each vineyard
.
🍇The Cavolo vineyard sits on a hilly slope on the estate. Sun-soaked and brilliant, these vines were originally planted in the early 1990s. Taking from the vineyard mainly grapes of Corvinone, Corvina, and Rondinella, the harvest is left to dry for 120 days. Once ready for the winemaking process to begin, this Amarone goes through double aging in two types of barrels. First in small barrels for 2 years, then finished in larger for 2 more
.
🍷The final result is a stellar and thought-provoking wine that is bold with fruit compote notes, sour cherries, vanilla, and hints of dried fruit and toasted spice notes. 
On the palate, the wine is bold, complex, elegant and velvety. This is an Amarone that will have your mind reeling with every sip
.
😉A perfect complement to the love holiday around the corner, find this bottle at the @LCBO
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you in for a glass?
.

🤩Who doesn’t love a bit of bubbles for Valentine’s Day - 🥂serving up some Prosecco with @ruffinowines
.
🍾Popping a bottle of bubbles is a classic move for a celebration. Celebrating the love in your life deserves a sparkling moment and if you haven’t given it a try, Prosecco Rosé yet Valentine’s Day is the perfect opportunity!
.
🤓Ruffino has been a long-time Prosecco maker. The winery has been synonymous with the red wine red of Chianti since its start in 1877, but they ventured northwards in 2010 and began making Prosecco as well. As of 2020 Prosecco, is the best-selling sparkling wine on the planet, and Ruffino one of the top 10 most popular brands
.
😉Popularity is not without great taste! The classic Ruffino Prosecco is filled with notes of apple, white peach, pear and soft citrus notes reminiscent of lemon cream; followed by a taste that is just a touch off-dry with fine and playful bubbles
.
🥂Like its original counterpart, Prosecco Rosé is just as loveable as classic Prosecco. It has not been long but Prosecco Rosé has made a boom in wine-lover’s glasses. A bright pink hue this is a wine crafted from the Glera Prosecco grape with a touch of Pinot Noir
.
🍷In the glass Ruffino’s Prosecco Rosé is filled with notes of strawberry, rose petals, red berries, and peach; followed by a palate that is rounder in texture and bubbles that feel a bit sultry
.
👉Find both these bottles of bubbly at the LCBO for your Valentine’s Day celebrations
.

🍷Low-Sugar Wines are here to keep your goals in check, even through Valentine’s Day - 📺Today on @chchtv 
.
🤓I often get asked, are low-sugar wines that much better for you?
🥂A low sugar wine is one that has less than 5 grams of sugar per litre, ideal for people that are looking to cut down on the amount of sugar they consume. And the best part is that the LCBO carries more than 850 wines that are naturally low in sugar and delicous. You might already have a favourite wine that’s considered low sugar – and not realize it
.
❤️With Valentine’s Day around the corner, wine of all kinds might be returning to your weekly enjoyment, but you don’t have to break all your good work to enjoy a glass!
.
🤩Today on @chch_morninglive, I dive into some delicious low-sugar wines with @timbolen all of which are available at the @LCBO
.
🙌Featuring:
🍷@lakeviewwineco Mindful Rosé VQA 
With 1g of sugar per serving and 8% ABV, this is a delightful rosé that has notes of summer strawberries, red currants and a very fresh palate
.
🍷@matuawine Sauvignon Blanc Hawke’s Bay
Coming in a total of 4g/L sugar, this Hawke’s Bay wine has beautiful fruit-leading aromas with a zesty lemon-like acidity 
.
🍷@mascotavineyards La Mascota Cabernet Sauvignon
This is a wine from Argentina’s Mendoza region, and while they are known for being great at Malbec, this is a region for amazing Cab. Filled with jammy fruit and earth notes and only 4g/L sugar, too
.
🍷@antonin_rodet Cotes Du Rhone AOC Red
A blend of Grenache, Cinsault, Carignan and Syrah, this southern France wine has flavours of cherry, raspberry, anise and light spice with a dry palate that is powerful, with 4g of sugar.
.
🍷@bonpaswines Ventoux Grande Reserve Des Challieres
A wine from the slopes of Mont Ventoux in the Vaucluse. Filled with notes of black fruits, spices, delicate herbs, olives and flowers, this wine has an impressive finish with only 2g of sugar
.

🍹For The Love of Sherry! - Shaking up a Valentine’s Day cocktail with @harveyssherry
.
🤩Harveys has been making Sherry for over 220 years. This was at a time when Sherry was popping off in England and often blended on the final leg in Bristol—birthing the Harveys Bristol Cream Sherry
.
🤓Times have since changed but the Sherry remains the same. Harveys is crafted from a delicate blend of delicate finos, aged amontillados, and ragrant olorosos to create a silky, mellow smoothness. Followed by aging American Oak butts through the traditional solera system bringing together wines aged between 3 and 20 years.
🥂The final result is a Cream Sherry that caramel coloured with notes of dried flowers, herbs, caramel, fig and dried citrus notes 
.
😉Alright, let’s get to the cocktail!
.
🍹Named - For The Love of Sherry!
This is a cocktail I crafted that is a take on the Screwdriver Cocktail, which puts this Sherry in the spotlight
✨In a cocktail shaker add ice and:
2oz of Harveys Bristol Cream Sherry
1oz freshly squeezed tangerine juice 
8 Dashes of Ginger Bitters 
1 Squeeze of Ms. Better Bitter Miraculous Foamer
Shake it all up and serve it in a fancy glass worth of a Sherry cocktail 
.
😍Light and refreshing with a slight kick this is a great cocktail to kick off an evening of celebrating love 
After all, Valentine’s Day is right around the corner 
.
👉Find the Harveys Bristol Cream Sherry at the @LCBO
.

🤓What does a more democratic version of winemaking look like? 🍷Tayú by @sanpedrowines is an example of the future!
.
🇨🇱Tayú is a winemaking project started in the southern Chilean region of Malleco, elaborated by indigenous Chilean families in the community of Buchahueico. The community, The Mapuche, which means “people of the land”, has a connection to the earth that goes beyond what can be understood ecologically
.
🍷The project is working with the Mapuche community to plant vineyard crops that are  cared for by various community members and play a role in the winemaking to create a wine that shows a sense of place
.
🍇Working with San Pedro’s winemakers to harness their intimate knowledge of the soils and craft a Pinot Noir that expresses origin. As for the name itself,  Tayú means “Ours” in Mapudungun. the language of the Mapuche people. further highlighting the collaborative efforts and nature of this project that looks to the future of wine
.
👉Find this wine with it is back in the @LCBO soon, it is delicious and the story behind the bottle to match is more than just a conversation point but a look into what wine could be in the years to come
.

🍷🥂Tasting through the wines of @palatinehillsestatewinery🥂🍷
.
🤓Palatine Hills Estate Winery has been around for longer than you might think. The Ontario winery first played a role as a grape grower before moving into the winemaking space. A history that is family-owned and goes back nearly four decades. 
😉If you are unfamiliar with their wines and bevies, I am tasting through 5 today!
.
🍷First up, the 2021 Wild and free Riesling 
A bright wine that has notes of lemon, lime, and citrus-driven vibes, with mineral notes and a touch of petrol on the nose. Followed by a tasting experience that is on the drier side with a lean and mineral-leaning finish 
.
🍷2021 The Chiller, Ramblers Series Sauvignon Blanc
Light in colour with green notes of lime, jalapeno, tart pineapple, and a touch of passionfruit. On the palate, this wine is citrus-driven with bright citrus notes and a high-acid finish 
.
🍷2018 '1812' Red (although the winery is now on the 2021 vintage)
A blend of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon and made in a Claret style, this is a lightly coloured wine that sees very low oak treatment. With notes of blackberry, black cherry, and plum with a touch of earthiness and tobacco. From the bright note the plate continue with a medium tannin wine that is vibrant and food-friendly
.
🥂We have the Ramblers Mountain Do Cider and the Raspberry Mixie Wine Seltzer in canned form.
✨The Mountain Do Cider is made from Ontario apples and is very expressive with fresh and candied apple notes, with a leesy funk that adds dimension. On the palate, this is a fun and crunchy, quenching drink. 
✨The Raspberry Mixie Wine Seltzer is a slightly bubbly, refreshing drink flavoured with raspberry essence with a slightly pink hue. With notes of all the raspberry flavours you can think of, with a touch of nostalgia that brings a very-berry vibe to the palate
.

🤩Reminiscing about drinking some Liquid Gold on this #wineWednesday
.
🥂A few weeks back in January, I got to go to a very exciting wine tasting. Tasting through Sauternes made by @chateau_bastor_lamontagne
Tasting through the marvel of winemaking that is Sauternes, including the:
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 2016 
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 2011
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 2009
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 2006
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 1988
🍷Château Bastor Lamontagne Sauternes 1986
.
🤓If you are not familiar with this gem of a wine, the happy accident that, when vinified, turns into liquid gold, let me fill you in. 
🍇Sauternes is made from a blend of Sémillon and Sauvignon Blanc, but a touch of Muscadelle can also be found in the mix. The grapes are left on the vine long enough to be affected by Noble Rot, the technical term being Botrytis Cinerea. A unique microclimate in the Garonne area of Bordeaux, where the wines are made causes this type of grape rot to happen. But like a good blue cheese, this is not a bad thing. While it might start looking a bit funny, when these grapes become wine, they are transformed into sweet nectar with notes of honeyed apricot, butterscotch, caramel, mango, ginger, marmalade, citrus, tropical fruit, and toasted baking spices. Sweet on the palate but with a lively finish picked up by the acidity of Sauvignon Blanc
.
🤩Château Bastor Lamontagne has a long history in Bordeaux and has made Sauternes over the last three centuries. Currently producing wine organically, they are making wine from vineyards a mere stone’s throw away from some very well-known names in the region
.
🍷The character of the wines as you taste from current vintage releases back into the 80s shows how Sauternes ages beautifully. Going from a ripe and rich style of wine with bold fruit notes to one that is sultry and expressive of age through colour and nutty-like flavours
.
✨Truly an amazing experience!
💁🏻‍♀️What are your Sauternes memories?

✨Happy Sunday everyone!
I rarely get to take a moment to myself. A moment to not think about work or wine and just be. I love that my love of wine is a full part of my life. It is always a blessing to me that I have been able to make my once hobby into what I do for a living, but it is rare that I get the chance to step away and not think about the daily/weekly/monthly/yearly goals I have and the steps towards them
.
This picture was shot during a recent trip to California. In between hopping from winery to winery, my partner convinced me to go on a hike through the redwood forests in the region. I will admit that this would not have been something I would have done on my own. And @shambhavi2005, you were right we needed to stay and hike much longer. This was a place that was breathtaking and awe-inspiring, trust me, because the picture doesn't do the feeling a full level of justice. The trees are so large, for me, they have a comforting way of reminding me that I am part of a larger world and only human

Now back at home in Toronto, working away on a Sunday to set myself up for the week, a thought popped into my mind that brought me back to the forest. While the winery touring and exploration into everything Napa will be out soon on this Sunday I am taking a moment to remember a different side of the world around me
.

🍷A blended Cabernet Sauvignon bringing together two worlds of winemaking through the lens of @magnottawinery
.
🍇Cabernet Sauvignon is grown around the world. One of the classic grapes of Bordeaux, wine-lovers have seen renditions of this variety made in South Africa, Chile and right here in Ontario too
.
🤓While you can taste all of that the grape has to offer from these varying terroirs in Ontatrio, International Domestic Blends are a wine category that bridges the gap, bringing international and locally grown grapes together in a blended wine that has a unique perspective in the glass. Showing the winemakers and a winery’s style of winemaking all in one sip
.
🍷The 2017 Gran Riserva Cabernet Sauvignon from Magnotta is a 100% Cab Sauv production blending grapes from their Niagara and Chilean vineyards. Aged two years in French and American oak hybrid barrels, this is a blend that brings out aromas of tobacco, toasted vanilla, dried plum and cherry, cassis, earthen and woody notes. Followed by a palate that is inviting with great balance and sweet tannins
.
😍Serving this wine to myself today, I have a feeling I’ll be enjoying it as some winter food. In store for me is Dahl and rice, but this wine would be a delight to pair with heartier meat dishes or roast veg
.
👉Find this wine at the Magnotta stores or online, as of March 1st you will find this Cab Sauv on sale at $25.95
.

🍇A more inclusive future of wine - taking a look at @kenforrestervineyards
.
🤓A while ago, I read an article in @decanter by @gellietina about Ken Forrester's wine. I was struck by the quote Ken gave about his right-hand man @shawnmathyse. Just listen to the sheer admiration:
✨‘I have a protégé working for me – Shawn Mathyse; super smart, so switched on. Born on a wine farm and one of five kids – his mum was the housekeeper for a friend. He studied agriculture at Elsenburg in Stellenbosch and when he finished I said I’d take him on if he was willing. He’s got a passion for Chenin and you just know he’s going to be his own winemaker one day.’
.
🤩Having the chance to visit the winery myself and taste through the lineup with Ken and Shawn IRL it was clear how much the two have a passion for what they do - making wine. Ken is a phenomenal winemaker and seeing how Shawn was in a space to learn and grow in his own way is what got my mind thinking about the future of what wine looks like 
.
🥂Black History Month is coming to an end today, but that doesn't mean there is no longer a need to support black-made and black-owned wines. Actually, this is a time to look through your own year and see how you can do your best to lift everyone up. Like the relationship between Ken and Shawn, the more you can give to those around you in a positive way, the more they can grow. 
😉Shawn if you are reading this I can't wait to taste the next vintage and all your future projects!
.
✨Mentorship, leadership, friendship, and support are what we need to create a more equitable future in wine. And it is something you can taste in the glass too!
🍷This 2021 Old Vine by Shawn and Ken is bright, expressive and filled with minerality. It is everything a good Chenin Blanc from SA should be
.
💁🏻‍♀️How will you use your world this year to lift up voices of colour around you?

🥂It’s Candid Wine Review Time! Today with @vinatarapaca Gran Reserva
.
🍷This wine from the Maipo Valley blends Carmenere 71 %, Syrah 19 %, and Cabernet Sauvignon 10 %. Listen in for all the tasting notes
.
🤓Don Francisco de Rojas y Salamanca started the winery at the foothills of the Andes mountain range in 1874. 🤓Although we can assume that women have been a part of winemaking from the beginning, they didn’t have considerable power in wine for such a long time. 🥃What's the deal with Irish Whiskey? 🍀Happy #stpatricksday if you are not in for wine today; Irish Whiskey is the drink to sip!
.
😉While most of the time, you will find me sipping on a glass of wine. Recently, I got the chance to brush up on my Whiskey knowledge, so with the holiday if full effect, why not dive into some fun facts to get better acquainted with Irish Whiskey!
.
🥳This is a day to celebrate for many, and historically Irish Whiskey has been a part of the celebrations. A big sales day. More than 5 million bottles of Irish Whiskey are consumed during the holiday week, it is not a time to drag an Irish Distiller away from the distillery
.
🥃The name Whiskey itself is a corrupted English version of the true name of the drink, called Uisce Beatha in Gaelic, meaning water of life. And while there are some stored roots in the past and the creation of Irish Whiskey, the first mentions of the spirit date back to around the 12th/13th centuries 
.
🤓What sets Irish Whiskey apart from other global creations of the spirit is more than just the "e" in Whiskey. Irish Whiskey is crafted with a blend of malted and unmalted barley, which is then turned into a very strong beer and distilled using a pit still distilling phase. Usually triple distilled to boot, which makes for a smoother and higher ABV spirit to match
.
🍀Though it might not look like Irish Whiskey would have a strong link to wine history, I have to get you to think twice about this. Way back when Phylloxera plagued the vineyards of Europe, and before things got back on track, Irish Whiskey gained a lot of popularity in the place of wine. And like wine, the process of making Whiskey has also travelled the world
.
🤩The number of Irish Whiskey lovers grows and grows. You can visit the Gloden Triangle region in Dublin and visit so many distilleries now. With over 40 to hit up compared to only two back in the 80s
.
🥳How ever you choose to celebrate today, add a glass of Irish Whiskey to it. It seems only fitting
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you an Irish Whiskey lover?

🤩The Pétrus of the southwest - 🍷Below Bordeaux and truly captivating are the wines of @montusbouscasse
.
😉A funny thing happens when you start to dive down the rabbit hole in wine learning. You start to learn about rockstar winemakers. These winemakers might not be the names on everyone's lips globally, but they certainly are in the wine world. And they usually happen to be people that have put a region/style/winemaking philosophy on the map. Alain Brumont is one wine rockstar!
.
🤓Called The Man of Madiran, the creator of the Tannat Cathedral and maker of one of the most collectable fine wines outside of Burgundy and Bordeaux in France, Alain is a force that has made an impression around the world. Owner of the Château Bouscassé and Château Montus Alain is known for his winemaking style that can only be described as supra-biodynamic. There is a level and care in the vineyards to the final release of the bottle that oozes quality and intention with every sip. And you don't have to be a wine professional to feel it
.
🍇Having a winemaking career that started at the age of 16, back in the late 70s, and today working alongside his third wife Laurence and her son Antoine, Alain is 70 and still going. If by now you are wondering why Alian and his winemaking life have been so monumental, I must say it is the full embodiment of one key wine concept. Staying true to terroir and native grapes through and through
.
🍷This person has crafted stellar and cellar-worthy wines with Petit Courbu, Petit Manseng and Tannat (of course). All grapes are native to the southwest. And while Bordeaux is directly above the region, his vineyards harness the unique micro-climate it is sitting on, allowing for wines that breathe life and power. With wines like the Montus Sec White which has bold resonance, and the ever-collectable Montus Cuvée Prestige, which breaks down what you might think of Tannat from an inky, dense wine to one that is elevated, vast and grand
.
💁🏻‍♀️Have you tried the wines of Brumont yet?

.

🍇The Naramata Take on the Burgundian and Beaujolais Grapes 
.
🤓Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Gamay, grapes that have found well-suited New World homes in Canada, are growing within the bounds of the Naramata Bench. Today I am diving into just a few bottles that the region offers!
.
🍇Starting with Chardonnay. Chardonnay can tell you the feel of a place and a winemaker, no matter where it is made.
🍷@upperbench Winery and Creamy’s minimalist winemaking style is shown through their Estate Grown Chardonnay. An expressive wine with a natural edge brings out honey, caramel, pistachios, citrus, fruit notes of dried banana, peach and apricot. Crafted in a style that fully integrated barrel aging with fermentation and an additional 8 months
.
🍷Burgundy is the vibe at @foxtrotvineyards a winery captivated by the Naramata, with vineyards on the upper benchland their second line, the Foxly Pinot Noir has a bright and playful expression with a backbone of strength and stamina in the glass. Mixing together fresh cherry notes with touches of savoury thyme and nutmeg. Compared to the style of Pinot Noir, closer to the lakelands, this is a beefy wine
.
🍷Keeping the Pinot Noir flowing @tightropewinery is showcasing the other side of the region. The winery’s Rubis Pinot Noir has beautiful spice notes of white pepper and clove but is far more dominated by the fresh fruit and floral notes radiating from the glass. This single vineyard production bottles up all the sunshine the region is known for
.
🍇Thriving in higher altitudes and cooler climates Gamay has been a hit across Canada.
🍷The Founder’s Block Gamay Noir by @hillsidewinery  is crafted from vines planted in 1984. This single vineyard production is filled with raspberry and cedar notes and has a more bombastic feel than the Beaujolais version
.
🍷The @deeprootswinery version of Naramata Gamay is more floral leaning with wildflowers and red berry fruit notes, followed by a lifted but spiced palate
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you a fan of these Naramata wines?

🍇Here’s to a grape that loves a view! Sipping on some @naramatawines Syrah
.
🤓From Northern Rhône to the Canadian north, Syrah is a grape with a loyal fan base. The Northern Rhône Valley of France is home to this robust and thought-provoking grape. This region is characterized by its vast sloping landscape, creating an ability to bring the best out of the grape. There are a lot of similarities between the Northern Rhône and Naramata Bench when it comes to terroir
.
🍇While this is a grape that changes its tone from place to place, one thing is sure Syrah is a grape that likes a view. Doing best in wine regions with elevation and slope
. 
⛰️Coming from the Upper Benchland @tightropewinery and @nicholvineyard present two takes on Syrah. One is of the present, and the other a production with a nod to the past, with an old vine Syrah
.
🍷The Tightrope Syrah is a classic call back to the Northern Rhône Valley done with a conferment of 6% Viognier. This is a wine that is profoundly pulling. Filled with notes that start off floral but lean into dark fruit notes, cacao, leather and earthen notes
.
🍷The Nichol Vineyard Old Vine Syrah brings to life a vineyard planted in 1990 and 1991. This is a confident wine made from a 17 rows block of old vines and a solely Syrah production. Filled with Dark berry fruit notes, black licorice, black pepper and a rich but elegant palate.
.
😉Although Syrah is not everyone’s go-to, I know I am a loyal fan of this grape. Tasting what is capable of in the Naramata Bench is truly a delight!
.
💁🏻‍♀️Are you a fan of Syrah?

🍇Bordeaux Grapes, In Far Off Lands with @naramatawines
.
🤓Renowned for its blends, Bordeaux and its grapes have made a clear impression on the world. The grapes of Bordeaux thrive in places where climate, soil and sunlight come together. This combination of all things good for the Bordeaux grapes of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc is a careful balance. One that is clearly found in the Naramata Bench. Creating wines with herb and spice undertones that are complex, well structured and have a great backbone of acidity that adds a balance and a nod to the cooler climate of the region
.
🍷Single-variety productions like the @3sisterswinery Cabernet Franc show so much potential in the glass. This is a wine that is worthy of some cellaring.  In youth, the wine is bold with black and plum notes on the nose, followed by bell pepper notes and complexity on the palate. This wine can age five to ten years and will show the best of itself.
.
🍷However, Bordeaux styles wines living the name to the fullest are blended productions. @blackwidowwine crafts its signature blend, the Hourglass Reserve, from Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon.  With vineyards located on the south end of the Naramata region, this is a wine with booming notes of ripe black fruit, dark cherries and touches of earth, sprinkles of mocha, dried herbs and a toasted finish
.
🍷@rochewines is the epitome of Bordeaux winemaking in Naramata Bench. With a history that stretches back to the home region in France, their Roche CHÂTEAU combines a blend of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc, unfined and unfiltered with barrel ageing. Bold with dark fruit notes, stony minerality and a subtle touch of oak, this wine brings concentration and precision
.
💁🏻‍♀️Have you had a Naramata wine inspired by Bordeaux?

🍷#CaliforniaWineFridays are here! @robertmondavi 2019 Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon
.
🤓Robert Mondavi has been a force in Napa Valley ever since he launched his winery in 1966.  Mondavi was the first major winery to open in Napa post-prohibition. The style of wine was one that embraced old-world techniques and combined it with pioneering concepts of modern winemaking and marketing that pushed the brand and the wines forward.
.
🍇From varietal labeling to the great To Kalon Vineyard, Robert Mondavi winery lead the way in introducing sustainability efforts, research and wine education to create wines with great range from budget-friendly and affordable wines to high-end premium knock-outs that are great for cellaring. 
.
🙌Robert Mondavi wines are a familiar brand, because of all of this rich history.  When it comes to Cabernet Sauvignon, Mondavi has been well-known since 1972, when his 1968 Cab Sauv was named the best wine by the LA Times. So while I won’t be sipping on something that back-vintaged today, I am taking a moment to reacquaint myself with the Cabernet Sauvignon of Robert Mondavi in the present.
.
🍷The 2019 Cabernet Sauvignon features Cab Sauv as the dominant grape in this wine, at 80% with 11% Merlot, 5% Petit Verdot, 3% Cabernet Franc and 1% Malbec rounding out the blend. This wine is made from grapes grown in the Napa sub-avas of Oakville, Stags Leap District, Oak Knoll, Yountville and Rutherford, with French oak ageing.
.
😍This wine is bold and beaming with notes of cherry, ripe plum, dates, sage, sandalwood, mint and a touch of vanilla bean.  The palate strikes large across the tongue with dripping tannins, rich black fruits, warm spice and a velvet-like texture.
.

🚨📖New Article Drop in @monarch.wine📖🚨- 🍷Exploring The Wine of BC’s Naramata Bench
.
🍇DISCOVER one of Canada's most gorgeous and unique wine regions!
🤩Follow the long and snaking Okanagan Lake southbound, and you will find the beautiful views and vineyards of the Naramata Bench wine region. On the eastern side of the lake and just a short drive from the city on Penticton, the Naramata Bench is defined by sun-soaked vineyards and constant rushing breezes that flow from the Okanagan Lake. This region formed out of glacial movements is home to various soil types and grapes that grow there. To translate the wine-geek speak, Naramata Bench is a place that has a broad spectrum of wines just waiting to be tasted, defined by bright and refreshing acidity, with powerful aromatics and a memorable expression in the glass.
.

🍷#CaliforniaWineFridays 🤩sipping on some Zin with the @michaeldavidwinery staple, 7 Deadly Zins
.
😉Fun fact.  Did you know that the oldest Zinfandel vines in California are in the Shenandoah Valley which is just a hop, skip and a jump from Lodi? 
🍇This California AVA is where more old vines of Zin grow than anywhere else in California. So it is not surprising to see a Lodi winemaker like Michael David Winery go all in on Zin!
.
🤓Lodi and the winery go way back, about 150 years, to be exact. The connection started in the 1860s by Michael and David Philips, brothers and 5th-generation grape growers.  The winery is a family legacy that continues to thrive with a reputation for making wines with sustainability at heart.  Their wines are bold and delicious and adhere to the Lodi Rules of winemaking which follows a 100-point practice that considers everything from social and environmental sustainability.
.
🍇Zinfandel, an obsession in Lodi,  is a needed part of the winery’s repertoire and all 7 Deadly Wines are sourced in the Lodi AVA.  Zinfandel is well suited to the region because it loves mild temperatures with warm days and cool nights, making for a wine that has a tempting nature in the glass. 
.
🍷To create this unique wine, there are seven Old Vine Zinfandels blended together. Made with 80% Zinfandel and 20% Petite Sirah for structure and depth, this wine is filled with notes of jammy red and black fruits, leather, oak spice note and dark mocha tones. The palate is layered with dark fruit.
.
😍This is definitely a wine for a bold wine lover.  Find this bottle at the @LCBO 
🙌And if you are in for discovering more Zinfandels, get your tickets to:  EUREKA: The California Wine Discovery coming to Toronto on May 8th, where you can sip Zin to your heart’s content

🍷The revolutionary effect that kicked @stagsleapwinecellars into the wine zeitgeist
.
🤩One of the wines that launched Napa Valley into the world’s mind, Stag’s Leap Wine Cellars is the Stags Leap District AVA darling that astonished the palates of wine lovers with its 1973 vintage at the Judgement of Paris and has not stopped for a second since!
.
🍇The Fay and S.L.V vineyard soils define their wines. An alchemy of fire and water, the S.L.V Soils are volcanic in nature, and the Fay is alluvial. creating a fire and water blend of sorts, which can be tasted in the Cask 23 blend of the two soil types. While the Fay on its own is more rustic and floral and the S.L.Vfilled with girt, power and intensity
.
🍷Variations across the Fay Cab Sauv, that encompasses the whole soil type across a large swath of vineyard plots, the Heart of Fay  Cab Sauv and the Fay Hillside bring o light the depth of this terroir in the glass. Starting with more fruit-forward and plumy rendition that have gritty tannins, moving to aromatic floral and candied nut notes, and ending on the hillside with a wine that is earthy and lead by more levity in the finish
.
🍷On the S.L.V side of winemaking, the Cab Sauv and Cab Franc from the vineyard plots show wines that are filled with brilliant true fruit notes and touches of mineral depth, followed by palates that have a plushness and iron-like feels that bring forward nuance and the spirit of the terroir fully
.
😍The cherry on top of the tasting experience is getting to the Armillary Cab Sauv. The 2017 vintage is a co-ferment of both soil types. An all into one wine that is bold and full of soul, with an expressive and stewed finish that brings the full breadth of all the vineyards together
.
🙌There is no stopping the winemaking at Stag’s Leap!
.

😍Blending wine is an artful endeavour
🍷Today I’m sipping on the @magnottawinery Art of Blending White
.
🤓Blending is part of the winemaking process through and through. Even wines with a sole-grape varietal have a blended component, whether a vineyard or barrel selection blend. However, blended wines that combine multiple grapes represent an expression similar to cooking with many different spices. Each grape in the blend shows a different side of its character and melds with the others to create a new expression that shows what the winery and the region at large is able to deliver
.
🍇The Art of Blend White Wine from Magnotta brings together 	Pinot Grigio, Chardonnay, and Sauvignon Blanc. Each grape is fermented separately and assembled to create the final wine. Resulting in a fresh and vibrant wine that has a presence on the palate
.
🍷Notes of peach, pear and white nectarine and brought by Pinot Grigio. Chardonnay contributes apple, star fruit, lemon and soft citrus notes. And Sauvignon Blanc adds tropical notes, lime and touches of herbal characteristics. On the palate, each grape combines to present a wine that is led by bright acidity, vibrant mineral notes and a lengthy finish 
.
🤩This VQA Ontario wine is a delight to enjoy on its own, but it is excellent paired with light fare and dishes with a touch of spice. Perfect for the spring season, this is a very of-the-moment wine
.
🥂Part of the Venture series wines by Magnotta, while this is a wine you can enjoy on the daily it, is also a wine that gives back. With proceeds from every bottle going to support the G. Magnotta Foundation for Vector-Borne Diseases to benefit Canada’s first Lyme Disease translational research lab at the University of Guelph
.
😉Loving these tasting notes?
👉Find this wine at Magnottta stores, the @LCBO or have it ordered to your door just in time for a patio hang 
.

#CaliforniaWineFridays 🍷Sipping Cab Sauv done Paso Robles-style, with the @jlohrwines 2020 Hilltop Cabernet Sauvignon
.
🤓California not only has Napa as a great producer of Cabernet-driven wines!  5 hours south, past the southern reaches of Napa and even Monterey, is Paso Robles. This wild-hearted region makes for some amazingly bold Cabernet Sauvignon wines
.
🍇Many still consider Paso Robles the California wine industry’s wild west. The region as a whole is characterized by an innovative spirit that blends traditional techniques with modern technology to create superior wines in the heart of Central Coast Wine Country.

🤩A classic winery for the wild west of wine,  J Lohr is a brand synonymous with the region. Through winemaking and the work of its owner and founder, Jerry Lohr, J Lohr has helped put Paso Robles on the map. Often called the “Robert Mondavi of the Central Coast,” Jerry was drawn to the rich soils and dramatic diurnal shift in the region and was a visionary in thinking that Paso would be an ideal place for making Bordeaux grape wines
.
🍷The J Lohr Hilltop is a Certified Sustainable California production made from grapes grown on the estate’s Shotwell Vineyards in El Pomar District, which comprise  the majority of the blend. The fruit is sourced from higher-elevation vineyards including the winery’s Beck Vineyard in Creston District and mountain fruit from the Adelaida District
.
🤓Spending 18 months in barrel, the majority of which are new, French oak, this is a big, bold wine. While Cabernet Sauvignon is the main attraction here, there are small amounts of Petite Verdot, Malbec and Cabernet Franc that form the final blend.
😍Aromas show layers of blackberry, black currant and sweeter toasted notes, with a rich, robust  palate and a long finish
.
🍾Find this wine at the @LCBO

🍷The howling mountain lion of Mt. Veeder @mayacamaswine
Here are my thoughts in the glass on what Mayacamas encompasses
.
🍷2010 Chardonnay 
Aromas of mushrooms, dried apricots, Sungold raisins, white hydrangea flower and lemon curb. Developing, herbal, and textural, with a spiced finish and a very complex vibe
.
🍷2018 Hill Block Chardonnay 
Candied apple note, pear puree, Indian guava, caramel, dulce de leche, apricot and sundried fruit. Boldly textured, with fresh fruit quality, a round finish, plum wine notes and a touch of oak tannins
.
🍷2020 Chardonnay 
Tart apricot, yellow apple skins, starfruit, button mushrooms, lemon curd, toast, and an expanse of aromatics. Textured palate with grit and expressive flavours, with a bright and fresh finish
.
🍷Terraces Chardonnay 2019
A rocky aroma wine with a cooler vibe of leaner fruit notes or yellow apple, lemon, pomels and mushroom earthiness. The palate is a bright collection of mineral notes and crunchy acidity
.
🍷2018 Cabernet Sauvignon 
Blackberry, maraschino cherry, tobacco, allspice, fennel seed, toast, vanilla, and black cocoa. With grainy tannins that reach high, meaty acidity and earthen-dark fruit tones
.
🍷2012 Cabernet Sauvignon 
Herbal and cherry notes, twiggy earth notes, tobacco, cumin and a touch of spice. Developing, it is expressive but needs more time in the bottle
.
🍷2003 Cabernet Sauvignon 
Filled with cherry, plum, dried cranberry, earthy, licorice, cocoa, and Mexican spiced chocolate aromas. Complex, vibrant, relaxed and ready to drink
.
🍷2012 Merlot 
Plush and plummy with blackberry, strawberry, and black floral notes and a toasted feel. Plush with aged structure and great balance
.
🍷Merlot 2002
This is a fruit-leading wine with plum, prune, blackberry, currant and earth notes with bold florals. A lovely structure on the plates with grace and yumminess
.
🍷1990 Pinot Noir 
Fully developed with stewed cherry, poached pear, cranberry, and bomb floral notes. Developed and a sipper, with a bright finish that is highly complex
.

🍷#CaliforniaWineFridays Organic wine done right with @bonterra - 😁Yes, I’ll have a glass of Chardonnay!
.
🍇Bonterra and formerly Fetzer Vineyards have been making organic wine before it was common culture. The winery has gone all-in on organic winemaking and has made wine in this style since 1993. Now the leading organic winemaker in America, they have dropped the Fetzer name some time back and go solely by “Bonterra”
.
🤓The winery has proven that persistence and good winemaking are what pays off in the end. After all, we are in a day and age now where if wine is organic without sacrificing flavour and quality, it is a top buy. And Bonterra and wineries like them around the world are the shepherds that have led us to this point
.
🌱Bonterra is B Corp Certified, Regenerative Organic Certified, Climate Neutral Certified and TRUE Zero Waste Certified. On top of all this, it is essential to note that the first steps in the process started back under the Fetzer name in 1987.  The Fetzer family’s values spread beyond the vineyard, giving back to the industry and society at large in the process
.
😉With all that good-good, I bet you are dying to know how the wine tastes!
🍷The Bonterra Chardonnay is filled with notes of pear, green apple, citrus, flower blossoms, and a soft spice note which is complemented by a bright, rich textural palate. 
🍇While the leading grape is Chardonnay, this very aromatic wine is aided by additions of Muscat and Viognier in the blend. Finished in oak, this is a wine that can be drunk now or held onto for a couple of years to explore a more mature form of organic winemaking in the glass
.
👉Find this wine at the @LCBO

🍷#CaliforniaWineFridays Cool-Climate Rosé is where it’s at with @lacremawines Monterey Pinot Noir Rosé!
.
🤓Originally La Crema Vinera, meaning the “best of the vine,” La Crema is obsessed with making cool-climate wines. The Monterey AVA is not always your first thought when thinking of cool-climate wine regions but the long valley of the AVA stretching from the cold Monterey Bay to the southeast reaches of the Salinas Valley is a region with an ever-present breeze and a maritime influence from the cold Pacific currents running inland
.
🍇The region is known for growing Pinot Noir and Chardonnay primarily–two grapes that thrive in a cool environment.  These two varietals love the cool, foggy mornings and the warm, windy afternoons, making for wines that have tension, brightness and levity in the glass
.
🍷This 100% Pinot Noir Rosé is made in an artisanal, small-batch style which brings to life aromas of orange blossom, ripe watermelon, raspberry strawberry, peach, and flinty mineral notes.  The palate is highly expressive with bright acidity, lean structure and a finish full of vibrancy and finesse.
.
😉Find this cool-climate wonder at the @LCBO 
And discover more soon!

🍷Getting into some delicious @180wines - Comming up on our big Mother's Day Event on May 13th @trinitymarketto
.
🤓One of the factors that always drew me to explore beyond the glass was the story a wine could express. One of a winery, the people behind it and the wine they make. When you talk wine with winemakers and winery owners, it is clear how a passion for wine drives them. The feeling of bottling up a living, breathing beverage that we can smell and taste is connective on so many levels
.
🍇Family-owned and operated winery by the Murdoch Family, the story of 180 Wines is literally in its name. With her two daughters, Taylor and Sara, and husband Bob, Marzia and her family decided to change their lives. Craving to reconnect with nature and pursue their passions, the family jumped on an opportunity to own and operate a winery in Niagara wine country. They sold their family home in Mississauga, left corporate jobs and pulled a complete 180 in their lives
.
🥂Their Sparkling Rosé, which has been recognized with a winning medal from the National Wine Awards Canada as one of the best in Ontario. Made with estate-grown Gamay grapes and done in Charmat Method (like Prosecco), this wine brings exuberance and vibrancy to the glass. Filled with red fruit notes, floral tones and a delightful finish. 
🍷And 180 Wines also produces a delicious Pinot Grigio made using estate-grown grapes with a bright and citrusy flavour profile. This wine is perfect for sipping on a warm summer day and shows what Ontario's terroir can do with this Italian grape
.
